summary: This document is a chain of emails from 2020 between the FBI's NY CART Coordinator and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The emails discuss logistical challenges, data formats, and the massive volume of evidence from multiple devices. This document is an email chain between the FBI's New York office and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) regarding the organization and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York mansion and Virgin Islands properties. It highlights the massive scale of the evidence (over a million documents, dozens of devices) and the logistical challenges in tracking and reviewing it.

persons.name: N. (NY) (FBI)
persons.role: NY CART Coordinator Senior Forensic Examiner
persons.context: An FBI forensic examiner in New York coordinating the transfer and accounting of digital evidence seized from Epstein properties. They provide status updates on what evidence has been handed over.

connections.description: They are corresponding professionally regarding the transfer and review of seized digital evidence in the Epstein investigation. The FBI examiner is providing evidence to the AUSA's team.

events.title: Search of Epstein Property
events.description: A search was conducted on one of Jeffrey Epstein's properties, resulting in the seizure of 9 IDE hard drives (3 copies of 3 drives).

events.title: Search of Epstein Residences
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands, and upon his person at arrest, seizing numerous digital devices.

events.title: Search of Epstein Residences
events.description: Search warrants were executed at Epstein's residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands, and upon his person at arrest, seizing numerous digital devices.

events.title: FBI Update on Epstein Evidence Transfer
events.description: An FBI forensic examiner emails the U.S. Attorney's Office with an update on the status of digital evidence seized from Epstein's New York and Virgin Islands properties, noting network issues and what items have been produced.

events.title: AUSA Requests Evidence Tracking System
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney sends an email expressing that it is 'impossible' to track the evidence received without a proper labeling and tracking system, given the volume (over a million documents) and lack of device identification.

events.title: New Evidence Folder Received
events.description: A folder of evidence labeled 'NYC024362' with a modified date of January 27, 2020, is received, containing over 600,000 items. The AUSA is unsure if it is new material.

locations: New York mansion (Epstein's New York property)
keyFacts: The FBI's NY CART team was processing terabytes of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties, including phones, tablets, loose media, cameras, DVRs, servers, laptops, and desktop computers.
Evidence included items from a July 2007 search of an Epstein property, where 9 IDE hard drives (3 copies of 3 drives) were found in his Manhattan apartment.
The U.S. Attorney's Office needed the data in a specific, searchable format (for Relativity) to conduct discovery and taint review, but faced challenges with prior data transfers being unusable.
The correspondence indicates significant staffing and logistical challenges (including pandemic-related reductions) that delayed the evidence processing and transfer timeline.
The evidence list referenced specific device types not yet transferred, including 2 Macs, a DVR, an iPhone, and an iPad from the New York searches, and additional 'Island stuff'.

Digital evidence seized from Epstein's properties was massive, involving approximately 40+ storage devices and 60+ CDs from the New York mansion, and more than 25 devices including servers from the Virgin Islands.

The U.S. Attorney's Office received a hard drive with over a million documents but lacked a system to identify which devices the materials came from or what was new versus previously received evidence.
The FBI confirmed that CDs from the New York search 'only contained pictures, no documents' and that an initial screen was conducted to check for child pornography (CP), with the answer being 'no'.
An FBI forensic examiner cited internal network upgrades requiring the deletion of 'about 400 TB worth' of data as causing a delay in their response.
The correspondence underscores significant logistical and organizational challenges in processing the vast amount of digital evidence in the Epstein case post-arrest.
